DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

US CDC COVID-19 cases rose to 4275 in latest update (prev. 3536) and death toll rises to 75 (prev. 68). (Newswires)

US President Trump said administration will look to provide USD 50bln for airlines and USD 250bln for small business loans via emergency stimulus according to an official, while President Trump said 'hopefully' the US will not need a national lockdown. (Newswires)

White House is reportedly considering plan which could amount to stimulus of USD 1.0tln-1.2tln to tackle the fallout from the coronavirus outbreak, according to sources familiar with the matter. In related news, US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that President Trump has authorised deferral of USD 300bln in IRS payments in which Americans can defer up to USD 1mln in payments and corporations USD 10mln to IRS, while the government is looking at sending checks to Americans in 2 weeks. Furthermore, Mnuchin stated we intend to keep markets open but added there could come a time where trading hours are shortened. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi said House Democrats are working on third COVID-19 response act, while there were comments from US Senate Majority Leader McConnell that the Senate will not adjourn until bold measures are passed that go beyond the economic relief bill. (Newswires)

New York Mayor de Blasio said he is “absolutely considering” a shelter in place order for New York City residents just like the one instituted in California’s Bay Area on Monday. (CNN)

UK reported total coronavirus cases rose to 1950 (Prev. 1543) while deaths increased to 67 (Prev. 53). (Newswires)

UK Chancellor Sunak announced new measures including cash grants, tax holidays, mortgage moratoriums and lending facilities, with government interventions to be made in the economy on an "unimaginable" scale. The measures include GBP 330bln of guarantees for business and noted that if demand is greater, then as much capacity as is required will be provided and that every single shop, pub and others in hospitality will pay no business rates for 12 months. Furthermore, to support liquidity for larger firms, there will be a new lending facility and to support lending to SMEs, business interruption loan scheme will be extended in which both schemes will be up and running by next week. Mortgage lenders will offer a 3-month payment holiday for those in need and the NHS will get whatever funding it needs, while further measures will be announced in the coming days. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson said although measures are extreme, we may have to go further and faster in the coming days and are doing all we can to increase NHS capacity, while he later stated we are keeping the situation regarding schools under continuous review. (Newswires)

EU Leaders agree to close borders to prevent virus spread; borders will be shut for a 30-day period Canadian PM Trudeau stated that Canada is planning to bring Parliament back briefly to pass emergency economic measures in which it will be recalled for legislation regarding methods of getting money to citizens. (Newswires)

 

ASIA-PAC

US President Trump said he took exception to China suggesting that the US brought the virus into China and said it is accurate that the virus came from China. (Newswires)

BoJ bought a total of JPY 121.6bln (Prev. 101.4bln) ETFs on March 17th. (Newswires) 

 

UK/EU

Group of asset managers told BoE Governor Bailey that financial markets should close for two weeks, according to WSJ citing sources. The call was held with senior executives from asset managers including Vanguard Group, BlackRock Inc. (BLK), JPMorgan Chase & Co. (JPM) and Bank of New York Mellon Corp (BK), in which the industry is said to have told Bailey that most mutual funds weren't seeing large outflows yet. (Newswires)

  • UK Employment Change (Jan) 184k vs. Exp. 143k (Prev. 180k)
  • UK ILO Unemployment Rate (Jan) 3.9% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.8%)
  • UK Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Jan) 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.2% (Prev. 3.2%)
  • German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Mar) -49.5 vs. Exp. -26.4 (Prev. 8.7); ZEW said the economy is on red alert.

 

FX

Turkey Central Bank cut its one-week repo rate by 100bps to 9.25%, while it noted that weakness in TRY is offset by lower oil prices and that new data or information may lead the Committee to revise its stance. Furthermore, it stated that keeping the disinflation process in track with the targeted path requires the continuation of a cautious monetary stance. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (w/e 13th Mar) -0.42mln vs. Exp. +3.3mln (Prev. +6.4mln). (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia is reportedly to boost oil exports to a record of 10mln BPD. (Newswires)

 

GEOPOLITICS 

US Secretary of State Pompeo said US is imposing sanctions on 9 entities in South Africa and China for helping Iran. (Newswires) 

 

US

Fed said it will establish commercial paper funding facility (CPFF) to support credit flow, providing liquidity backstop to CP market through special purpose vehicle purchasing unsecured and asset-backed paper rated A1/PI as of March 17th directly. (Newswires)

Fed’s Kashkari (dove, voter) said Fed hasn’t used all its ammunition and does believe the slowdown will be a mild one, while he doesn't have interest of going below zero interest rates but doesn't rule out the measure and noted that all are watching the commercial paper space closely. (Newswires)

  • US Industrial Production (Feb) M/M 0.6% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. -0.3%, Rev. -0.5%) 
  • US Retail Sales (Feb) M/M -0.5% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.3%, Rev. 0.6%)

 

MARKET RECAP

After a grim session on Monday, equities rebounded, though trade was extremely choppy, particularly after the open as pre-market retail sales data highlighted that the economy may have been facing some headwinds even before the virus began spreading, while industrial and manufacturing production data was mixed. There was speculation out of the gate that the Fed would step into the commercial paper market to continue addressing the funding stresses; the Fed made the announcement official in morning trade. The risk complex was also supported by governments around the world continuing to pledge huge amounts of fiscal support for companies and individuals to get through the crisis -- in the US, the package could be worth between USD 850bln and USD 1.2trln, according to multiple sourced reports (Mnuchin himself suggested around USD 1trln). Equities ramped after a press conference with President Trump, where the Treasury Secretary suggested that direct check payments (of around USD 1,000 in the next two weeks) to Americans was on the cards. SPX +6.0% at 2535, NDX +6.5% at 7474, DJIA +5.2% at 21237.

The Treasury curve bear-steepened with yields up over 11bps in the front of the curve, and up over 30bps in the long-end. Analysts said the moves were a result of an equity rebound after steep declines on Monday. However, the key was the Fed stepping in to support the commercial paper market, which analysts aid was a key source of funding stress, and havens saw outflows as a result. The haven bid was deflated as governments came along with massive stimulus measures and guaranteeing loans to try and backstop the potential downside from the coronavirus. There was even some talk about profit-taking in the long-end after some very big moves, of late. US T-note futures settle 2 points lower at 136-02.

Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 17th March 2020: Equities surge as policy makers make it rain stimulus
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, Dollar up, Crude down.
  • REAR VIEW: Fed steps into commercial paper market; US mulls USD 1.2trln stimulus; UK launches stimulus worth 15% of GDP; soft retail sales, mixed manufacturing and industrial data.
  • COMING UP: Data: EZ Final, US Building Permits and Housing Starts, Canadian CPI, DoEs, New Zealand GDP, Japanese Nationwide CPI. Event: German Finance Minister Scholz to present draft budget. Supply: Germany.

MARKET WRAP:

After a grim session on Monday, equities rebounded, though trade was extremely choppy, particularly after the open as pre-market retail sales data highlighted that the economy may have been facing some headwinds even before the virus began spreading, while industrial and manufacturing production data was mixed. There was speculation out of the gate that the Fed would step into the commercial paper market to continue addressing the funding stresses; the Fed made the announcement official in morning trade. The risk complex was also supported by governments around the world continuing to pledge huge amounts of fiscal support for companies and individuals to get through the crisis -- in the US, the package could be worth between USD 850bln and USD 1.2trln, according to multiple sourced reports (Mnuchin himself suggested around USD 1trln). Equities ramped after a press conference with President Trump, where the Treasury Secretary suggested that direct check payments (of around USD 1,000 in the next two weeks) to Americans was on the cards. Desks also noted that the VIX remains extremely elevated, although analysts at Goldman Sachs pointed out that intra-day volatility has been declining; the bank believes that the swings into the close suggest that market participants view end-of-day price moves as fundamentally unjustified, and the moves are perhaps being exacerbated by equity derivatives, ETFs, and fund rebalancing. Meanwhile, the configuration of gains today saw utilities leading the charge higher (despite US yields seeing chunky rises -- desks note the defensive nature of the sector, the potential for high dividend growth, while there are even some talking about value in the sector), followed by staples as consumers stockpile essentials. Energy was the laggard, the only sector in the red, taking its cue from the crude complex.

COVID-19:

US FISCAL MEASURES: The Trump administration is considering an economic stimulus package between USD 850bln to 1.2trln (depending on which sources you believe) to help support the economy manage the outbreak. The Administration is also mulling directly sending Americans checks to ensure consumers have cash to get through the worst of the crisis (potentially a USD 250bln measure). It also increased the amount of tax payments that can be deferred by business (up to USD 10mln), and for individuals can defer tax payments up to USD 1mln for 90 days, both interest and penalty-free. Loans to SME would account for USD 300bln of stimulus, and there would be USD 200bln allocated for unspecified stabilisation measures. The Treasury Secretary also said that he was aiming that markets remain open, though he did suggest that shorter trading hours may be needed at some point. Senate Majority Leader McConnell says it is too early to say if he supports elements of the White House coronavirus stimulus plan.

UK FISCAL MEASURES: The Government announced measures totaling GBP 330bln (of government backed loans), or 15% of GDP, to support the economy through coronavirus; "If demand is greater than that, will provide as much as capacity as is required," the chancellor said. The funds will be made available via a new lending facility for large firms with BOE, and for SMEs through an extension of a loan scheme announced last week. The Chancellor said there would also be a 12-month business rate holiday for all firms in retail, leisure and hospitality sectors; cash grants of up to GBP 25k per qualified business. There will also be cash grants for small businesses, and the size was increased. For consumers, there will be a three-month mortgage holiday for homeowners.

NEW YORK: Mayor de Blasio says he is “absolutely considering” shelter in place order for New York City residents just like the one instituted in California’s Bay Area on Monday, according to CNN. This would effectively put NY in lockdown. EUROPEAN RESPONSE: EU Leaders agree to close borders to prevent virus spread for a period of 30-days. Ministers also discussed joint debt issuance, according to German Chancellor Merkel, though no conclusion was reached; joint debt issuance has been a thorny subject for Germany, and even discussing the measure was interpreted as a positive by participants. EU Commission's Von der Leyen says EU state aid rules will be flexible so governments can support their companies.

CENTRAL BANKS:

FED COMMERCIAL PAPER FACILITY: The Fed said it will re-establish a commercial paper funding facility (CPFF) to support credit flow, which would provide a liquidity backstop to the market via a special purpose vehicle, which would purchase unsecured and asset-backed paper rated A1/PI as of March 17th directly. Pricing would be based on the then-current 3-month OIS+200bps – a markedly more attractive price for corporates than what current market spreads offer. The central bank noted that the commercial paper market was under "considerable strain" in recent sessions due to the COVID-19 outbreak. The facility should eliminate risks in the market and improve companies' ability to maintain employment and investment through the outbreak, the Fed said. The CPFF was last used in the wake of the 2008 GFC.

FED’S KASHKARI (DOVE, VOTER): said the Fed hasn’t used all its ammunition and doesn't have an interest of going below zero interest rates, although doesn't rule out the measure either – comments made in a CNBC interview. As calls grow for the Fed to step into the commercial credit markets, Kashkari noted the Fed is watching the space closely. On the approaching slowdown, the Minneapolis Fed President said he believes it will be a “mild one”. Later, Kashkari said the virus outbreak will quickly become an economic crisis for the US, which could quickly become a recession; says it could be a long crisis, adding that the right reaction is to overreact to provide the best outcome.

FED’S MESTER (HAWK, VOTER): said that she supported all actions in the emergency FOMC meeting, but not the 100bps rate cut. She argued that lowering interest rates has less of an impact in the current environment, and she had preferred to retain the option of using cuts in the future.

DISCOUNT WINDOW: Bank of America (BAC), Bank of New York Mellon (BK), Citigroup (C), Goldman Sachs (GS), JP Morgan Chase (JPM), Morgan Stanley (MS), State Street (STT) and Wells Fargo (WFC) have begun tapping the Fed’s, previously stigmatized, Discount Window for funding. The Fed cut the rate it charges to the lending facility by 150bps to 0.25% on Sunday, the upper end of its target FFR, greatly increasing its allure for banks. Fed Governor Quarles has been vocal in the past about taking measures to encourage usage of the facility.

NY FED OPERATIONS: The Desk carried out its 14-day Term repo operation, which oversubscribed, accepting USD 45bln in bids (USD 46bln submitted). It then carried out its O/N operation, accepting all USD 142.65bln in bids submitted (USD 500bln offered after upping it from USD 175bln). The GC rate remained above the top-end of the FFR prompting the NY Fed to come in the market for a second O/N offering, as it did on Monday, which tamed the GC rate beneath the 0.10% stop-out rate and saw a much less USD 10.10bln amount in bids submitted.

ECB: The ECB allotted EUR 109bln in its new three-month LTRO operation. Elsewhere, the Bundesbank said it has not seen increased cash withdrawals in the past two weeks, according to German press.

BOC: Bank of Canada reiterated that it was ready to cut rates further and to deploy other market tools if required, to support growth and keep inflation on target. Regarding Friday’s rate cut, it said Policymakers concluded there could be a considerable benefit to reducing interest rates immediately.

CBRT: The Turkish Central Bank opted for an emergency 100bps rate cut ahead of its scheduled meeting on Thursday, bringing the one-week repo rate to 9.75%.  Mounting fears over the virus outbreak prompted MPC members to conduct an emergency meeting earlier in the day. The Central Bank noted that the recent Lira weakness is being offset by the slump in oil prices. The statement did, however, note that the “weakening in global trade and measures such as travel restrictions; the disinflationary effect of aggregate demand conditions has increased to some extent.” Although the cautious stance has been maintained, the CBRT “emphasized that any new data or information may lead the Committee to revise its stance.” Furthermore, the Bank unveiled measures including the provision on TRY liquidity, with a rate 150bps below the one-week repo, through repo auctions with maturities up to 91 days. Amid the unsettled financial conditions, the CBRT also stated it will provide banks with as much liquidity as they need, via intraday and standing overnight facilities.

NBP: Polish Central Bank cut its key interest rate to 1.0% (Prev. 1.5%) in an emergency move, Lombard rate cut to 1.5% (Prev. 2.5%), Rediscount rate cut to 1.05% (Prev. 1.75%). It also cut its reserve requirement rate on PLN and foreign currency funds held in bank accounts to 0.5% (Prev. 3.5%).

EQUITIES:

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +6.23% at 2535, NDX +6.46% at 7474, DJIA +5.19% at 21237.

SECTORS: Utilities +13.11%, Cons Stpl +8.39%, Real Estate +6.94%, Technology +6.77%, Materials +6.65%, Health +6.26%, Financials +5.77%, Industrials +4.2%, Cons Disc +4.03%, Communication Svs +3.99%, Energy +0.72%.

Stock Specifics: Defensives (XLU, XLP) saw heavy gains today with Ameren (AEE) and Consolidated Edison (ED) leading the utilities, perhaps finding solace from news that Pacific Gas and Electric (PCG) received bankruptcy court approval to use up to USD 23bln (11bln debt, 9bln new equity, 3bln through new shares) in financing after California Governor Newsom withdrew his opposition against the move, as the co. continues its aim to move away from its Chapter 11 bankruptcy. Staples were led by gains in Church & Dwight (CHD) and Clorox (CLX) given both companies are sellers of cleaning supplies. Clorox (CLX) announced it is producing as much products as possible but urged customers to only purchase what is needed.  Health Care (XLV) saw solid gains also, Regeneron (REGN) announced its coronavirus antibody programme has the potential to start human clinical studies by early summer. Baxter (BAX) reported solid earnings, although guidance was weak. Foot Locker (FL), L Brands (LB), Nordstrom (JWN), Ulta Beauty (ULTA) and Tiffany (TIF) are the latest to temporarily close its stores in an attempt to limit the spread, while Apple (AAPL) extended the closure of its non-China stores until further notice. FL, LB, JWN and ULTA also withdrew its guidance, as did Hilton Grand Vacations (HGV). Uber (UBER) & Lyft (LYFT) suspended its shared rides on its platform throughout the US and Canada to help prevent the spread. Amazon (AMZN) announced in a tweet it will be suspending shipments other than medical supplies and household staples. On airlines, US President Trump’s administration is reportedly looking at stimulus proposals for the airline sector, according to Washington Post. Southwest Airlines (LUV) withdrew FY20 guidance, while noting its load factor (month to date) was roughly 67%, although in recent days it is heading towards 50%. The airline also will reduce its Available Seat Miles (ASM) by 20% from April to June. Meanwhile, source reports suggested that American Airlines (AAL) is in discussions to borrow billions in new debt and Delta Airlines (DAL) is in talks to raise USD 4bln in new debt. Elsewhere, Dow (DOW) rallied after its CEO announced its demand in China has bounced back in recent weeks. In late trade, reports suggested that Boing (BA) was reportedly seeking "tens of billions" in government support.

BANKS: US Banking Regulator has repeated the call for banks to use capital and liquidity buffers to support the economy and businesses; regulators are proposing a rule change to make sure bank payouts gradually reduced if buffer breached.

CRUDE:

CRUDE SETTLEMENT: WTI (J0) settled USD 1.75 lower at USD 26.95. Brent (K0) settled USD 1.32 lower at USD 28.73/bbl.

Crude benchmarks reversed earlier gains in line with the session’s evolution of risk appetite. After a strong selloff on Monday, the benchmarks made gains, alongside equities, in the overnight session before reversing course into US trade. On the supply side, Saudi announced it is now raising its production to 10mln BPD as part of its efforts to ramp up production to 12.3mln BPD in April. Saudi Energy Minister also said that the Kingdom’s sudden increase in crude exports is due to utilizing gas produced by its Fadhili plant to compensate for about 250k BPD of domestic oil production. Elsewhere, Goldman has cut its Q2 Brent forecast to USD 20/bbl (prev. USD 30/bbl); the analysts also forecast US production to fall by over 1mln BPD between Q3 2020 and Q3 2021 – note there is generally a time-lag for producers to respond to shifts in oil prices. Although Total (FP FP) announced on Tuesday that it is adapting its refinery output in France to meet the current demand situation.

BONDS

TREASURY SETTLEMENT: US T-Note futures settle 2 points lower at 136-02.

TREASURIES: The Treasury curve bear-steepened with yields up over 11bps in the front of the curve, and up over 30bps in the long-end. Analysts said the moves were a result of an equity rebound after steep declines on Monday. However, the key was the Fed stepping in to support the commercial paper market, which analysts aid was a key source of funding stress, and havens saw outflows as a result. The haven bid was deflated as governments came along with massive stimulus measures and guaranteeing loans to try and backstop the potential downside from covid. There was even some talk about profit-taking in the long-end after some very big moves, of late.

FOREX:

FX WRAP: The dollar surged, driven higher by funding pressures, and ignoring the liquidity ramp being offered by the Fed; the buck now flirts with YTD highs around 99.915, though has not managed to touch it yet. The EUR lost out as the buck gained, given rate differentials moved sharply in favour of the buck (see Treasury wrap above). Outflows from havens and yield differentials also resulted in USDJPY rising to almost touch 108.00. GBP fell to a fresh YTD low also managed to bounce after the government announced a massive programme to support the economy, although at pixel time is still languishing by almost 2%, it remains above 1.20. The Antipodes are heavily lower, despite the bounce in risk sentiment, taking their cues from the mighty buck. Commodity FX (RUB) was weighed as crude prices continued to find fresh YTD lows. The CAD fell to a four-year low, with many desks now expecting further action from the BOC. The TRY and ZAR managed to rise, with the latter eying the SARB meeting on Thursday, where it is expected to cut rates, although any easing is seen as limited.

Daily FX Wrap: DXY back within striking distance of ytd peak
content:
USD

The Buck and index have been bid for the bulk of Tuesday’s EU session in stark contrast to see-saw trade in stocks and bonds alongside several counterpart currencies. Funding and liquidity factors are still driving demand for the Dollar, to the extent that disappointing US retail sales data was largely overlooked amidst reports that more fiscal stimulus is in the offing (as much as Usd850 bn touted). In fact, the DXY even inched higher and closer to February 20’s 2020 high (99.915), at 99.776 when the Fed rolled out a CPFF to specifically target strains in the credit market.

EUR/AUD/GBP/CHF/JPY/NZD/CAD

None of the Greenback’s major rivals have been able to evade selling pressure for more than periodic phases, and some hardly at all, with the Euro now underperforming and probing bids ahead of 1.0950 after breaching the 200 DMA (near 1.1100) and digesting a grim ZEW survey. Meanwhile, the Aussie lost grip of the 0.6000 handle awaiting further policy action from the RBA in under 48 hours (repo and maybe even QE) and Cable careered through 1.2200 and 1.2100 on the way to a circa 1.2030 irrespective of an encouraging jobs and earnings update. Similarly, the Franc trod cautiously into Thursday’s SNB quarterly policy review and breached 0.9600 and the Yen reversed from around 105.88 beyond 107.50 following a rise in BoJ ETF buying. Back down under, the Kiwi only gleaned fleeting momentum from a Nzd12.1 bn fiscal support package before retreating to 0.5935 at one stage and its Canadian peer was already under pressure beneath another big figure/psychological level when the BoC issued a statement underlining its willingness to ease further and use other tools if needed to prop up the economy and keep inflation on target. Usd/Cad now approaching 1.4200.

SCANDI/EM

Some respite for the beleaguered Norwegian and Swedish Kronas on the back of a net (but far from consistent) improvement in risk appetite that filtered through to oil and some other commodities, while EM currencies witnessed contrasting fortunes after another spate of emergency rate cuts. The CBRT got today’s ball rolling with 100 bp reductions in the key 1 week repo and accompanying benchmark rates, while slashing the RRR on FX reserves by a whopping 5 full points, and the NBP subsequently followed its CEE3 compatriot, CNB, with a ½ point ease. Eur/Nok has eased back between 11.06020-11.3240 extremes and Eur/Sek was capped just ahead of 11.0000, but Usd/Rub remained elevated above 75.0000 as the Brent/WTI spread converged to less than a Buck, if not altogether and the Mxn and Brl both hit fresh all time lows vs the Usd before reclaiming some lost ground.

Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 17th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

17th March 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1300GMT/0900CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

  • Of note for Banking names (GS, WFC, BAC, C, MS), JP Morgan (JPM) issued a statement noting it is actively supporting the use of the discount window as it is an important part of the financial system. Fed officials and other regulatory officials have encouraged banks to start utilising the rate.
  • Of note for Casino names, further casino closures have been named from Penn National Gaming (PENN), Boyd Gaming (BYD), and Eldorado Resorts (ERI).
  • Of note for Airlines (LUV, DAL, UAL, AAL), US President Trump’s administration is reportedly seeking stimulus proposals for the sector for about USD 50bln, according to Washington Post.

Dow Jones

  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) announced 11 employees tested positive for the coronavirus while 339 are under quarantine. The statement noted public health officials would determine whether production continues at its at its factories, according to WSJ. Elsewhere, the jet manufacturer is said to seek short term aid as part of talks with the White House.
  • Dow Inc. (DOW) (Materials/Commodity Chemicals) CEO states its demand in China has bounced back in recent weeks, says its dividend is artificially high due to the current market environment, meanwhile oil prices are not sustainable.
  • Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) announced it is looking to significantly reduce spending due to the current market conditions and fall in commodity prices.
  • JP Morgan (JPM) (Financials/Diversified Banks) is reportedly being probed for market manipulation of Treasury securities and futures contracts, according to WSJ citing sources.
  • McDonalds (MCD) (Consumer Discretionary/Restaurants) announced it is to close seating areas in its US restaurants.
  • Pfizer Inc. (PFE) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) and BioNTech (BNTX) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced it has come to an agreement to co-develop and distribute a potential coronavirus vaccine.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centers) has been upgraded to Outperform from Perform at Oppenheimer. Where analyst Rupesh Parikh believes the company is well positioned to meet its FY20 guidance and it could benefit from money flows shorter-term investors are to look for safety in a time of uncertainty. Parikh gives a PT of USD 125/shr (Prev. close 106.76).

Nasdaq 100

  • Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) announced it is opening 100,000 new full and part time positions across the US.
  • American Airlines (AAL) (Industrials/Airlines) is reportedly in discussions to borrow billions in new debt in wake of the coronavirus pandemic, according to sources. 
  • Illumina (ILMN) (Health Care/Life Sciences Tools & Services) announced it has entered into a global strategic partnership with IDbyDNA to bring next generation sequencing based workflow to the microbiology market across the globe.
  • Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) announced its procedures in countries such as China, South Korea, Italy and Taiwan have been disrupted due to the coronavirus, noting it could see a material impact on its financial results.
  • JD.com (JD) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) announced it has authorised a USD 2bln share repurchase programme.
  • Regeneron (REGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) says its coronavirus antibody programme has the potential to enter human clinical studies by early summer, noting it has identified “hundreds” of virus-neutralising antibodies and is planning for large scale manufacturing by the middle of April with an antibody cocktail therapy.

S&P 500

  • Delta Airlines (DAL) (Industrials/Airlines) is reportedly in discussions to raise USD 4bln in new debt in wake of the coroanvirus pandemic, according to sources.
  • Foot Locker (FL) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel Retail) announced it has withdrawn its FY20 guidance and it is to temporarily close its stores in North America, EMEA and Malaysia until the end of the month.
  • Hologic (HOLX) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) announced the FDA gave the co. emergency use authorisation for its new coronavirus test.
  • L Brands (LB) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel Retail) announced it is withdrawing Q1 earnings guidance amid the coroanvirus pandemic and the uncertainty it is bringing to its operations. LB also announced it is to temporarily close its stores in the US and Canada. LB also have chosen to draw down USD 950mln from its revolving credit facility.
  • Nordstrom (JWN) (Consumer Discretionary/Department Stores) announced it has withdrawn its FY20 guidance and suspended its share repurchase programme, while also closing its stores for two weeks to limit the spread.
  • Ralph Lauren (RL) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) is to temporarily close stores across North America until the beginning of April.
  • Regions Financial (RF), PNC Financial Services (PNC), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) (Financials/Regional Banks) and Northern Trust (NTRS) (Financials/Asset Management & Custody Banks) announced they have suspended its share repurchase programme through Q2, in fitting with other banks yesterday.
  • Southwest Airlines (LUV) (Industrials/Airlines) announced it is withdrawing its FY20 guidance, notes its load factor (month to date) was roughly 67% and recent days it is trending towards 50%. As the coronavirus pandemic continues, LUV expect revenue for the remainder of Q1 and all of Q2 to deteriorate further. In response to the pandemic, LUV will reduce ASM by 20% from April 14th to June 5th, 2020. It is also initiating a hiring freeze and offering voluntary leave options for its employees.
  • The Clorox Company (CLX) (Consumer Staples/Household Products) announced it is producing as much products as possible, asking customers to only purchase what they need so there is enough for everyone.
  • Thermo Fisher Scientific (TMO) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) CEO announced the company is to ship tests to 200 laboratories in the US, while also noting it is to ramp up production to 2mln tests per week, then looking ahead it looks to ramp up production to 5mln a week.

Other

  • Brookfield Renewable Partners (BEP) and TerraForm Power (TERP) (Utilities/Independent Power & Renewable Electricity Producers) announced the two entered into a definitive merger agreement, for BEP to acquire the outstanding shares of TEP, other than the 62% owned by BEP and its affiliates, where each TERP share will be acquired for 0.381 of a BEP unit.
  • Hilton Grand Vacations (HGV) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Restaurants & Leisure) announced it has withdrawn its guidance for FY20 but announced a new USD 200mln share repurchase programme.
  • Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG) (Utilities/Electric Utilities) received bankruptcy court approval to use up to USD 23bln (11bln debt, 9bln new equity, 3bln through new shares) in financing after the California governor Newsom withdrew his opposition against the move.
  • Tencent Music (TME) (Communication Services/Entertainment) Q4 19 (RMB) EPS 0.80 (Prev. Y/Y 0.57), revenue 7.29bln (Prev. Y/Y 5.4bln)
  • Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Road&Rail) announced it suspending shared rides on its platform throughout the US and Canada to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.              
  • Volkswagen (VOW3 GY, VWAGY) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) announced it is to temporarily pause production in Europe, according to CNBC.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 17th March 20
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities found mild reprieve following touted US stimulus measures; Spain’s IBEX outperforms on short-selling ban
  • US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin is said to be seeking USD 850bln package or more of stimulus, according to Politico citing sources
  • In FX, the Greenback gains more ground above 99.00 vs. a sub-98 low, as such G10 pairs are pressured
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US retail sales, industrial production, business inventories, APIs, EZ finance ministers meet

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Mainland China reported 21 additional cases of coronavirus and 13 additional deaths on March 16th vs. Prev. 16 additional cases and 14 additional deaths on March 15th, bringing the number of total cases in mainland China to 80881 and death toll to 3226. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 84 additional coronavirus cases for a total of 8320 and the death toll increased by 6 to a total 81, number of cured increased by 264 to a total of 1401. (Yonhap)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin met with GOP Senators and said he is seeking a large number for additional coronavirus stimulus legislation but did not elaborate on the size of the additional stimulus package, while he will discuss it with GOP Senators on Tuesday. There were also comments by US Republican Senator Rubio that Mnuchin asked Senate Republicans to move on additional coronavirus measure targeting airlines and small businesses this week. (Newswires)

US House passed a revised coronavirus bill which was sent to the Senate and there were comments from US Senate Majority Leader McConnell that aims to win Senate passage of the House-passed coronavirus legislation. (Newswires)

New Zealand announces NZD 12.1bln economic package accounting for 4% of GDP. There were also comments from Finance Minister Robertson that a recession is almost certain and that many will lose jobs, while he added that with businesses to fail and that this year’s budget will be the 2nd phase of broader recovery package. (Newswires)

German Finance Minister Scholz says it is too early to talk about ESM to provide aid to other EZ countries. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asia-Pac equity markets traded mixed and US equity futures hit limit up overnight as stock markets attempted to nurse the recent heavy losses that resulted to the worst day on Wall St. since 1987 and a near 3000-point decline in the DJIA for its largest point drop on record, despite the Fed’s recent emergency measures. The tone in Asia improved from the open spurring mixed views regarding a potential capitulation after the recent sell-off and some murmurs of a dead-cat bounce, although there were further supportive measures including a NZD 12.1bln economic package from New Zealand and the US House passing a revised

coronavirus bill, as well as efforts from the Trump administration for an additional measure targeting airlines and small businesses. ASX 200 (+5.8%) outperformed after a rebound from support at the 5000 level to recoup some of the prior day’s record losses of 9.7% and eventually post its largest intraday gain since 2008 with miners and financials front running the recovery, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) fluctuated between gains and losses with sentiment flimsy alongside an indecisive currency. Hang Seng (+0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were both positive in early trade but then reversed course/trimmed gains as early optimism across the region slightly faded and following further liquidity inaction by the PBoC, although reports have suggested the central bank may still reduce the Loan Prime Rate this week even though it opted to maintain rates in yesterday’s Medium-term Lending Facility. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower as they tracked the recent selling in USTs but with some of the downside later reversed after prices found a platform around 152.50 and with the BoJ also in the market today under a special operation for JPY 200bln of JGBs with 3yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0094 vs. Exp. 7.0141 (Prev. 7.0018)

Japan is reportedly mulling reducing I/L bond sales to JPY 300bln (Prev. JPY 400) amid the virus outbreak, sources state. (Newswires)

BoJ bought a total of JPY 121.6bln (Prev. 101.4bln) ETFs on March 17th. (Newswires)

US

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin is said to be seeking USD 850bln package or more of stimulus, according to Politico citing sources. (Politico)

CFTC is preparing for the likelihood that trillions of USD of financial market activity may be moved from exchanges and corporate office to homes. (WSJ)

Fed’s Kashkari (Dove, Voter) says Fed hasn’t used all its ammunition. (CNBC)

EU/UK

UK and EU can't decide how to hold this week's trade talks, but continue to explore alternatives, will be guided by scientific advice, according to Express’ Barnes. (Newswires)

UK Employment Change (Jan) 184k vs. Exp. 143k (Prev. 180k) (Newswires) UK Average Earnings (Ex-Bonus) (Jan) 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.2% (Prev. 3.2%)

German ZEW Economic Sentiment (Mar) -49.5 vs. Exp. -26.4 (Prev. 8.7); ZEW says the economy is on red alert. (Newswires) EU ZEW Survey Expectations (Mar) -49.5 (Prev. 10.4)

London TFL will be running at reduced services, according to Sky News. (Sky News)

EQUITIES

Choppy trade in the equity sphere [Euro Stoxx 50 +1.0%] following on from a mixed APAC session, as what seemed like a sentiment turnaround subsided in early EU trade - although reports that US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin is seeing a USD 850bln package later induced a modest bounce off lows. Major bourses are mixed with Spain’s IBEX (+2.4%) the standout outperformer amid after Spain banned short-selling for a month amid the virus-induced selloff. DAX 30 cash briefly dipped below 8500 before trimming some losses, albeit remain some way off its 9145 session high. CAC (-0.6%) failed to glean much support after AMF regulator’s announcement of a 24hr short-selling ban on 92 stocks vs. Spain’s carpet ban, although France’s measure seems more of a cushion against losses as opposed to a deterrent. Sectors are mixed with no clear reflection of the risk tone, with energy and material benefitting from the

overnight rebound in respective complexes. In terms of individual movers. Iliad (+18.0%) tops the gains in the Stoxx 600 post-earnings in which anticipated coronavirus losses are expected to be less severe than feared. Elsewhere, Pandora (-2.9%) withdrew guidance amid the outbreak and noted that China since Jan LFL sales fell 70-80% on a YY basis.

COMMODITIES

USD - The Dollar is firmer across the board after losing momentum during Monday’s global stock market swoon, with the DXY firmly back on the 98.000 handle and breaching resistance ahead of the next big figure (like February 13’s 98.810 high) amidst more reports of the White House mulling a big aid package (Usd850 bn or perhaps more). However, safer-havens are clawing back some lost ground as the mood remains extremely fragile on COVID-19 factors and ahead of US data (retail sales and ip) that could highlight more of the economic contagion like yesterday’s NY Fed manufacturing survey.

AUD/NZD - Minutes from the RBA’s March policy meeting did not offer anything new in terms of forward guidance overnight, but the Aussie is on the defensive in advance of Thursday’s new measures from the Central Bank that could include QE. Aud/Usd is slipping back towards 0.6000 and Aud/Nzd remains south of 1.0100 even though Nzd/Usd has retreated through 0.6000 and the Kiwi only got a fleeting fillip from Nzd12.1 bn fiscal stimulus in similar vein to the Aussie after Government and RBA cash/liquidity injections.

GBP/EUR - A relatively upbeat UK labour and wage report has been dismissed as too old or irrelevant in the context of nCoV, as the Pound weakens across the board towards 1.2100 in Cable terms and sub-0.9100 on the Eur/Gbp cross. Indeed, Sterling is marginally underperforming vs the single currency despite a dire ZEW survey that has pushed Eur/Usd below 1.1100 (close to the 200 DMA) and eyeing Monday’s session trough just under 1.1050.

CHF/JPY - The Franc and Yen are both off best levels vs the Greenback, but retaining an underlying bid within 0.9458-0.9554 and 105.88-107.18 respective ranges in advance of the SNB quarterly review and following ramped ETF purchases from the BoJ today.

CAD/SEK/NOK - The Loonie is trying to stop the rot after losing 1.4000+ status against its US counterpart and tumbling to new multi-year lows not far from 1.4100, while the Swedish Crown is weaker vs the Euro inches from 11.0000 in wake of the Riskbank unleashing QE, finally and lagging its Scandi peer the is benefiting from a degree of consolidation and comparative stabilisation in crude prices, albeit choppy and still trending lower.

CBRT lowered its one-week repo rate by 100bps in an emergency move,

FIXED INCOME

It’s akin to sell everything bar the Dollar again as debt futures remain depressed regardless of yet another tame/temporary revival in equites and other risk assets. Eurozone bonds are still underperfrming after the ECB’s relatively modest and ‘surgical’ policy stimulus, leaving Governments to take up the strain, but Gilts are also on the backfoot alongside US Treasuries in wake of a solid, but not spectacular 2049 DMO placement given natural sponsorship from funds at the longer end of the maturity spectrum. Ahead, some top tier US data and API inventories, the Eurogroup meeting, further UK and possible US anti-nCoV aid announcements.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures have trimmed overnight gains during early EU trade, with the latter dipping into negative territory as the sentiment/consolidation seen in the APAC session abated as the underlying themes persist.  WTI Apr’20 futures have extended losses below the USD 30/bbl mark, having earlier briefly breached the level to the upside, with the next pertinent support level at the YTD low around USD 27.40/bbl. Meanwhile, Brent May’20 underperforms its WTI counterpart given the OPEC rhetoric surrounding the global benchmark, with the front-

month contract back below USD 30/bbl and just off its YTD lows at ~USD 29.50/bbl vs. intraday high of USD 31.20/bbl. Meanwhile, the spread between the two contracts continue to narrow and currently stands at under USD 1/bbl vs. ~USD 1.30/bbl at yesterday’s close. Elsewhere, spot gold continues to bear the brunt of liquidating positions as investors convert to cash and remain on the sidelines. The yellow metal trades firmly below 1500/oz (200 DMA ~1498/oz) ahead of the 50WMA (1462/oz) and yesterday’s 1450/oz low. Similar losses are seen across other precious metals with Silver approaching 12/oz after fleetingly dipping below the figure during yesterday’s trade. Copper prices unsurprisingly conform to the risk-turnaround as prices slide further below 2.5/lb and eyes USD 2.0/lb for barriers.

  •   CAD moves past 1.41 but out-performs on positive US spillovers.

content: Gilts resumed Liffe relatively flat before hitting offers and tumbling to a 134.17 low vs Monday’s 135.02 settlement, but have subsequently rebounded firmly alongside Bunds from a 171.24 base as EU stocks hand back all and a bit more of their best recovery gains. However, the Short Sterling strip remains depressed bar front month March ahead of expiry awaiting jobs and wage data that could draw a little more attention given tentative signs of stabilisation in broad risk sentiment. Also ahead, the DMO’s Gbp2 bn 2049 auction and new stimulus from the Government to ease the economic/financial pain caused by the coronavirus.

content: The core Eurozone bond is conceding further ground ahead of the EU cash bourse opens on the premise that firmer equity futures will translate to index gains, while also taking heed of a recovery in Italian BTPs and latest pledges from various Governments to apportion funds towards the collective effort to counter the fallout from COVID-19. So, multiple weights impacting the 10 year German debt future that opened at 172.00 vs yesterday’s 172.17 close and attempted to bounce overnight, but only made it to 172.23 before fading against an increasingly bearish technical backdrop. Indeed, Bunds have just breached charts supports around 171.54 and 171.34 to expose 171.00 and an earlier February low at 170.99 vs 171.25, at worst thus far.

Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
17th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia-Pac equity markets traded mixed and US equity futures hit limit up overnight as stock markets attempted to nurse the recent heavy losses that resulted to the worst day on Wall St. since 1987 and a near 3000-point decline in the DJIA for its largest point drop on record, despite the Fed’s recent emergency measures which aggravated concerns regarding the magnitude of the coronavirus fallout. The tone in Asia improved from the open spurring mixed views regarding a potential capitulation after the recent sell-off and some murmurs of a dead-cat bounce, although there were further supportive measures including a NZD 12.1bln economic package from New Zealand and the US House passing a revised coronavirus bill, as well as efforts from the Trump administration for an additional measure targeting airlines and small businesses. ASX 200 (+5.8%) outperformed after a rebound from support at the 5000 level to recoup some of the prior day’s record losses of 9.7% and eventually post its largest intraday gain since 2008 with miners and financials front running the recovery, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) fluctuated between gains and losses with sentiment flimsy alongside an indecisive currency. Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) were both positive in early trade but then reversed course as early optimism across the region slightly faded and following further liquidity inaction by the PBoC, although reports have suggested the central bank may still reduce the Loan Prime Rate this week even though it opted to maintain rates in yesterday’s Medium-term Lending Facility.

FTSE 100

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Vehicle sales 10.96mln unit vs. Prev. 10.90mln units. Co. notes that 2020 is a very difficult year and the group is unable to provide any reliable forecasts as a result. (Newswires) Co. has a 2.9% weighting in the DAX30. Co. shares are higher by 1.7% pre-market.

·       Asia-Pac equity markets traded mixed and US equity futures hit limit up overnight as stock markets attempted to nurse the recent heavy losses

·       US President Trump suggested the worst of the virus outbreak could be over by July/August, perhaps later

·       US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin met with GOP Senators and said he is seeking a large number for additional coronavirus stimulus legislation

·       In FX, the greenback was lacklustre around the 98.00 level. EUR/USD was contained below resistance ahead of 1.1200

·       Looking ahead, highlights include UK labour market report, German ZEW, US retail sales, industrial production, business inventories, APIs, EZ finance ministers meet, supply from the UK

17th March 2020

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Mainland China reported 21 additional cases of coronavirus and 13 additional deaths on March 16th vs. Prev. 16 additional cases and 14 additional deaths on March 15th, bringing the number of total cases in mainland China to 80881 and death toll to 3226. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 84 additional coronavirus cases for a total of 8320 and the death toll increased by 6 to a total 81, number of cured increased by 264 to a total of 1401. (Yonhap)

G7 leaders said that stepping up the COVID-19 response is the foremost priority and will make efforts to increase the availability of medical equipment where it is most needed. Furthermore, they are mobilising the full range of instruments, including monetary and fiscal measures, while they ask central banks to continue to coordinate necessary monetary measures and finance ministers will coordinate on a weekly basis on the implementation of stimulus measures and other steps that could be taken. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the administration is not currently considering nationwide lockdown but looking at certain regions and suggested the worst of the virus outbreak could be over by July/August, perhaps later. Furthermore, Trump said the US may extend sick leave to companies with more than 500 people and that the US will back the airlines in which they told airlines they will help them and will backstop the airlines. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin met with GOP Senators and said he is seeking a large number for additional coronavirus stimulus legislation but did not elaborate on the size of the additional stimulus package, while he will discuss it with GOP Senators on Tuesday. There were also comments by US Republican Senator Rubio that Mnuchin asked Senate Republicans to move on additional coronavirus measure targeting airlines and small businesses this week. (Newswires)

US House passed a revised coronavirus bill which was sent to the Senate and there were comments from US Senate Majority Leader McConnell that aims to win Senate passage of the House-passed coronavirus legislation. (Newswires)

 

 

White House recommended 15-day nationwide guidelines to slow spread of virus and avoiding social gatherings, while the affected states should close schools and surrounding areas. (Newswires) San Francisco Mayor put the city on lock-down (shelter in place directive) until 7th April 2020 which forbids people to leave their homes without permission, while Washington DC Mayor ordered a 2-week shutdown of restaurants, bars, nightclubs, theatres and health clubs due to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

Canadian PM Trudeau announced that Canada will close its borders to non-citizens and non-residents although it won't apply to commerce or trade, while he will not rule out any measure to keep Canadians safe. (Newswires)

French President Macron said Schengen area borders in France will be shut from midday Tuesday in coordination with EU nations. Macron commented that citizens should work form and only leave for essential duties, while they will step up measures to limit peoples' movements and have called off second round municipal elections. (Newswires)

New Zealand announces NZD 12.1bln economic package accounting for 4% of GDP. There were also comments from Finance Minister Robertson that a recession is almost certain and that many will lose jobs, while he added that with businesses to fail and that this year’s budget will be the 2nd phase of broader recovery package. (Newswires)

Riksbank to boost asset purchases and take measures to facilitate credit supply, while it will support economic developments and avoid credit supply issues and increase loans to banks on favourable terms and will buy SEK 300bln of bonds. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asia-Pac equity markets traded mixed and US equity futures hit limit up overnight as stock markets attempted to nurse the recent heavy losses that resulted to the worst day on Wall St. since 1987 and a near 3000-point decline in the DJIA for its largest point drop on record, despite the Fed’s recent emergency measures. The tone in Asia improved from the open spurring mixed views regarding a potential capitulation after the recent sell-off and some murmurs of a dead-cat bounce, although there were further supportive measures including a NZD 12.1bln economic package from New Zealand and the US House passing a revised coronavirus bill, as well as efforts from the Trump administration for an additional measure targeting airlines and small businesses. ASX 200 (+5.8%) outperformed after a rebound from support at the 5000 level to recoup some of the prior day’s record losses of 9.7% and eventually post its largest intraday gain since 2008 with miners and financials front running the recovery, while Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) fluctuated between gains and losses with sentiment flimsy alongside an indecisive currency. Hang Seng (-0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.0%) were both positive in early trade but then reversed course as early optimism across the region slightly faded and following further liquidity inaction by the PBoC, although reports have suggested the central bank may still reduce the Loan Prime Rate this week even though it opted to maintain rates in yesterday’s Medium-term Lending Facility. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially lower as they tracked the recent selling in USTs but with some of the downside later reversed after prices found a platform around 152.50 and with the BoJ also in the market today under a special operation for JPY 200bln of JGBs with 3yr-10yr maturities.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a daily net neutral position. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0094 vs. Exp. 7.0141 (Prev. 7.0018)

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Sunak will be at PM Johnson's press conference tomorrow and is to unveil significant financial package on Tuesday to assist firms impacted by the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires/Daily Mail) British Chambers of Commerce said the UK

 

economy looks to be on course for its weakest growth since the global financial crisis in which it lowered its growth forecast to 0.8% from 1.0% for 2020. (Newswires)

FX

The greenback was lacklustre around the 98.00 level but off the lows seen in the aftermath of the Fed’s recent emergency measures. The greenback’s major counterparts were also uneventful with EUR/USD contained below resistance ahead of the 1.1200 handle, while GBP/USD was relatively unchanged around 1.2250 with price action stuck near its 5-, 10- and 20-Hourly moving averages. Elsewhere, USD/JPY briefly attempted a reclaim of the 107.00 handle but then faltered amid the indecisive risk tone, while antipodeans were range bound as New Zealand’s economic measures only spurred marginal gains for NZD/USD and after the RBA minutes from the March meeting proved to be a non-event in which it reiterated that the board was prepared to ease further to support the economy.

RBA Minutes from the March meeting stated that board is prepared to ease further to support the economy and it is to ensure financial system has sufficient liquidity. The minutes also noted that an extended period of low rates is required and that the board agreed coronavirus is to have significant impact on economy. Furthermore, RBA stated that Q1 growth is to be noticeably weaker than expected and that it is a hard to predict the length of slowdown, while it is very unlikely the virus would be contained in near future. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures partially recovered some of the prior day’s hefty losses in which prices slumped over 8% to briefly below the USD 29.00/bbl level amid the worst day on Wall St. since 1987 and bearish comments by Saudi Aramco’s CEO. Nonetheless, oil prices have since rebounded and briefly tested USD 30/bbl to the upside alongside the improved risk appetite and with focus now shifting to the latest stockpile reports beginning with private inventories due later today. Gold prices declined back below the psychological key USD 1500/oz level with the precious metal pressured despite the lacklustre greenback, while copper was choppy alongside sentiment in its largest buyer China. 

Venezuela President Maduro announced nationwide quarantine beginning March 17th and noted the price of Venezuelan oil has declined to below the cost of production. (Newswires)

US

The NY Fed’s Desk’s USD 500bln 30-day term operation and USD 175bln o/n op were both undersubscribed, the former seeing all USD 18.45bln bids accepted (500bln offered) and the latter seeing all USD 129.60bln bids accepted (175bln offered). However, despite more liquidity offered by the Fed, signs of stress remained in funding markets, as evidenced by FRA-OIS widening on the day, as well as the overnight GC rate spiking to 2.0%. The further tightening led the Fed to announce an additional overnight repo operation later on Monday, offering USD 500bln, seeing the rate move lower again on announcement, although still elevated significantly above the Fed’s new 0-0.25% target range. However, the later operation saw all USD 19.40bln bids accepted while the GC rate came back close to the FFR. Meanwhile, the Desk also carried out its ramped-up Treasury and MBS purchases across the curve – USD 40bln in Treasuries and USD 7.6bln in MBS on Monday. T-Notes (H0) settled 2 points and 8+ ticks higher at 138-02.

Ohio will order polls to close for Tuesday's Primary citing a public health emergency despite an earlier refusal by the judge to deny the request to postpone the state primary. (Newswires)

8 largest US banks announced plans to access US Federal Reserve's Discount Window, while they noted they are strong and well capitalized but are accessing it to reassure all banks they can use it. (Newswires)

Other News - RBI Governor Das stated that MPC meeting will have a clearer view regarding impact of growth and noted that it is important to make sure policy action is calibrated. Das added that there are many options on the table and will decide on timing of any rate cut based on evolving situation. Furthermore, Das stated they will update growth at the next meeting, while the central bank announced a INR 1tln liquidity infusion for banks through long-term repo operation and noted the banking sector should take immediate measures to manage risks. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade choppy and US equity futures briefly hit limit up as they attempt to recoup losses following Wall St's worst day since 1987
content:
Asia-Pac equity markets are mixed and US equity futures briefly hit limit up as stock markets attempt to nurse the recent heavy losses that resulted to the worst day on Wall St since 1987 and a near 3000-point decline in the DJIA for its largest point drop on record, despite the Fed’s emergency measures which aggravated concerns of how drastic the fallout was from the coronavirus pandemic. The tone in Asia initially improved amid further supportive measures including a NZD 12.1bln economic package from New Zealand and the US House passing a revised coronavirus bill, as well as efforts from the Trump administration for an additional coronavirus measure targeting airlines and small businesses, although the momentum later waned spurring murmurs of a dead-cat bounce. ASX 200 (+2.5%) outperforms after rebounding from support at the 5000 level to recoup some of the prior day’s record loss of 9.7%, with miners and financials front running the recovery, while Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) fluctuates between gains and losses with sentiment flimsy alongside an indecisive currency. Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were both positive in early trade but then reversed course as early optimism across the region faded and following further liquidity inaction by the PBoC, although reports have suggested the central bank may still reduce the Loan Prime Rate this week even though it opted to maintain rates in yesterday’s Medium-term Lending Facility.

In FX markets, the greenback is lacklustre around the 98.00 level but is off the lows seen in the aftermath of the Fed’s recent emergency measures. The greenback’s major counterparts are also relatively uneventful with EUR/USD contained below resistance ahead of the 1.1200 handle and after further restrictions including the European Commission proposal of a 30-day ban on incoming travel for foreigners and with France to close Shengen area borders from today, while GBP/USD is relatively unchanged around 1.2250 with price action stuck near its 5-, 10- and 20-Hourly moving averages. Elsewhere, USD/JPY briefly attempted a reclaim of the 107.00 handle but then retraced gains amid the indecisive risk tone, while antipodeans are range bound as New Zealand’s economic measures only spurred marginal gains for NZD/USD and after the RBA minutes from the March meeting proved to be a non-event in which it reiterated that the board was prepared to ease further to support the economy.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower as they track the recent selling in USTs but with downside stemmed as prices find a platform around 152.50 and with the BoJ also in the market today for JPY 200bln of JGBs with 3yr-10yr maturities under a special operation.

content:
